div1.ab: ah, the divine presence, existing in form of a cloud, over
will they put this load on us?—on the world?—on God?
dishah, a title for the Sultan or the Shah
Geometry, involves the rules of lines, surfaces, and solids.
This is no time to cut up carlacues—
The sweet sap trickles from the tree.
div1.l: Periphery, the circumference of a circle

div1.p:
The Literature of is periphrastic, full of pretty uttering numberless plays upon genteel ideas,—ornamental enough, but its elegance is like the elegance of parlors, full of crowded with china things, and bronze and gilt things, costly th knickknacks piled on curious shelves—the floor covered by a rich carpet—It is very circumlocutious, spreading perpetually out toward the edges, of—afraid of avoiding abrupt points and new born all unwashed facts, new born births, naked and or red—from the afraid of the bare rough ground, and of the going bare foot, or of entering the sea waves naked any way except concealed any how but with dressed in a complete bathing dress.—Very much of What we call The modesty of modern literature is unspeakably —that absence of in its negativeness, a million times, is more more filthy and rotten, than any positive blackguardism spoken in plain words.—A man writing for A writer speaking to select society dare not say that he takes it for granted that he cannot refer mention the greatest and most beautiful, delicate and tender facts traits cosmopolitan to each live all white and black and brown copper-colored humanity that is or ever was on earth, without putting seeing decent folks to flight skate at once from his presence: he cannot must not know he, as like any other being, was born grew in the womb of his mother and was born thence, like every honest man man boy- babe and every honest woman girl-babe,—Hhe must not know that feeling of a man for a his woman, and of a woman for a her man, which is originally clean and sweet as the kisses of Christ and sweet transparent mythic as the honey of the hives bees of Eden, and —an originality which only the men depart from in proportion as they are unnatural and the ignorant, and the farther they depart from it, the more they lose the gist of the very pleasure they seek.—I consider the my supposition True The literary modesty which she makes a studied
circuit bend outside of all such thin subjects, has scabs than the small pox, and a smell like worse foetida in multiplied to its tenth power.—Because its heart origin it ∧ sm to supposes as a fact acknowledges that the speaker and all each one who listens to him, have such within their breast has each one contains within his or her breast such a maggotty and putrid cispool of polluted thoughts, bad and buried impulses as never to hear these simple facts traits mentioned without attaching to them and sending thence answering thence a them with responses of a some carrion meanings or stenchy maggots desires—For myself I think of no more insulting supposition that one could toward me than anything of that such an one
True modesty ignores nothing in the world—it rather takes for granted that every thing is, in itself, beautiful and pure and benevolent.

"Let him who is without a taper be assassinated" this feat, the half-joking, half-earnest cry during the "extinguishment" hour of the last night of the carnival at Rome, when every body swarmed through the Corso, and public places, with tapers—each individual trying to preserve his own light and put out whosever else's he could.— This performance altogether is called "extinguishing the carnival."

Discord in dress: Travellers through Germany have told one of Jews at the great fairs, with—dressed At the great fairs in Germany travellers ta tell me they meet Jews dressed in flowing garments, with patriarchal beards—all surmounted on the head by the modern fashionable hat
Iambus—Iambic—Pope's the Ill Iliad is in iambuses long and short syllables alternately—"The sire—of gods—the aw-ful si-lence breaks"
Iambics—the old satyricalsatirical poems—festive toward Dionysus or Bacchus out of it which comedy grew—
